Comments_List: I learned many different techniques of optimization, along with better understanding of the theory behind it, with matrices, calculus.... It also improved some of my mathematical proof skills and coding skills with the homework. With the foundations of the class, and such a broad overview of the many different exciting techniques, I feel that I can read any paper of optimization and know more or less what they are talking about. Very very good course, probably my favorite one this semester.
Foundations for convex optimization
Theoretical background and intuitions behind basic optimization techniques.
Optimization skills. Dual problem.
Optimization techniques for different models
Different convex optimization algorithms
A lot of optimization algorithms.
different optimization methods
Many optimization techniques. Get familiar with this field and mathematical proves for these algorithms.

Great overview of optimization!
I learned a lot about different optimization techniques and proofs behind them. This class was difficult for me but I felt it made me a stronger mathematician.
solving convex optimization problem
optimization

The course was excellent! The homework were very relevant to the class material, the lectures nice to follow. Good textbooks and supplementary notes. Having a final project is also very nice to be able to understand better some of the material from the class.
The project was very useful in getting hands-on experience with what we learned. I felt that I learned the most from the problem sets where I could implement something.
The course is more theory-inclined than it seems, which helps establish a strong theoretical background that facilitates further learning and actual application.

I think the course gives a very good overview of a lot of important topics in optimization theory. The fact that the course is heavily theory based may deter some students, but I think that building a theoretical base is important rather than just focusing on applications. That said, I think the course could be improved by having some additional 'motivating examples' to give students a better idea of the type of problem that a certain technique would be applied to. Even though lectures might not cover any actual solution to these problems I think students would be better able to connect with the theoretical material if they were given a few more 'real' examples as motivation.

The course project is a good way to help students think about optimization in their own field of interest. While I appreciate the open ended nature of the project, I think that some additional guidance could be given during the term regarding some things such as general expectations for the main archetypes of projects that arise.

The course covered a lot of material, and some of them are recent research progress.

Some proofs are only sketched or skipped in class. I spent a lot of time taking and reviewing my own notes. It would be great if class notes were available.
Providing lecture notes would be better since sometimes it was hard to recognize handwriting on the blackboard.
Well-organized course.

The course is very organized. However, the instructor went to fast. It was hard to follow sometimes.

I'd recommend this course to students interested in learning about the mathematical theory of optimization. The class is challenging, many proofs but very nice if interested in this kind of area. And good foundations for many topics after, like in graph theory, machine learning, probability...
